forecast.rationale: This recall was issued 34 days ago (April 5, 2025), leaving 53 days until the resolution date. The total window of approximately 87 days (about 2.9 months) represents a moderately tight but not unreasonable timeframe for recall closure. Factors supporting closure: The recall involves only 22,000 pounds, which is relatively small in scale; foreign matter contamination may be simpler to address than bacterial contamination; and companies are typically motivated to resolve recalls quickly. Factors against closure: The recall has already been active for over a month with no indication of imminent closure; USDA/FSIS recall closure requires thorough verification that all affected product has been removed from commerce and that effective corrective actions are in place; many food recalls remain open for 3-6 months or longer. Without specific information about Johnsonville's progress on corrective actions or FSIS verification activities, I must rely on base rates for similar recalls. The fact that 34 days have elapsed without closure suggests this may be following a standard timeline rather than an expedited one. Given the status quo bias (recalls remain active unless actively closed), the lack of information about progress, and typical recall durations, I estimate a moderate but below-even probability. My forecast would be higher if there were reports of imminent corrective action completion or FSIS verification activities nearing completion. It would be lower if the recall scope expanded or if additional complications were reported.
